;一名因间谍罪在中国入狱的澳大利亚学者担心，如果他他的朋友周一表示，他没有接受治疗。

;

;出生于中国的澳大利亚人杨军（又名杨恒均）自 2019 年以来一直在中国入狱，在一次非公开审判中被指控从事间谍活动，罪名是重罪。受到人权活动人士的批评。

;

;杨的健康状况不佳是由肾脏上长出的一个大囊肿引起的，这引起了探视他在押期间的澳大利亚外交官的注意。

;

;“如果我的健康状况发生问题，我死在这里，外面的人不会知道真相，”他在最近与朋友和支持者分享的一份说明中说道。 “如果我出了什么事，谁能为我说话？”

;

;2017年被中国当局拘留和审讯的政治学家冯崇义表示，他越来越担心朋友的健康。

;

; p>;

;“这些监狱或拘留中心无法提供像样的医疗，”他说。

;

;“这让我深感担忧。当他们谈论进行一次去除囊肿的大手术时，这可能会危及他的生命。”

;

;杨否认间谍指控，并于 2019 年 1 月罕见地​​返回中国时被捕。

;

;杨否认间谍指控。 p>;

;澳大利亚作家杨恒均“对间谍指控不认罪”

;

;这位作家兼学者此前曾告诉支持者，他在秘密拘留所遭受酷刑，并担心可能会对其采取逼供手段。

;

;他的闭门审判于 2021 年中在北京举行，杨仍在等待判决。

;

;澳大利亚外交部长黄英贤办公室周一在一份声明中表示，政府对“他的案件持续拖延”表示“深切关注”。

;

;堪培拉与北京关系的改善引发了新一轮释放杨以及被监禁的澳大利亚记者成雷的行动——成雷也面临模糊的间谍指控.

;

;程最近在牢房里口述给澳大利亚官员的一封便条中描述了她惨淡的监狱条件。

;

;这条信息读到“我想念太阳”，被描述为一封“情书” ” 到澳大利亚。

;

;“在我的牢房里，阳光透过窗户照射进来，但我一年只能在里面站 10 个小时。

;

;“我想念我的孩子们”：澳大利亚人在中国被关押的主播发表第一份声明

;

;程自 2020 年 8 月以来一直被拘留，但直到 2021 年 2 月才被正式逮捕。

;

;去年 3 月，她在澳大利亚大使的陪同下接受了闭门审判前往中国的澳大利亚人被禁止进入法庭旁听诉讼程序。

;

;试图提出程和杨的困境的做法激怒了中国官员，他们此前曾敦促澳大利亚不要干预司法系统。

;香港财政司长表示，香港在拥抱在线娱乐的同时，不应将目光投向在线娱乐。下一代互联网，即 Web3，作为刺激经济增长努力的一部分。

;

;财政司司长陈茂波周日呼吁香港不要浪费任何时间，抓住机遇

;

;“下一波突破很可能由 Web3 和区块链技术推动，”他在每周博客文章中写道。

;

;香港陈茂波捍卫填海工程的经济潜力

;

;陈茂波表示，近年来Web3的应用和发展为用户提供了高品质的沉浸式体验，加速了在线娱乐行业的发展。< /p>;

;他强调了一项海外研究，该研究预测全球在线娱乐市场可能会从 2021 年的约 1840 亿美元增至 2027 年的约 6530 亿美元。

;

;“NFT 等， GameFi、Play to Earn 和沉浸式娱乐是许多全球娱乐企业投入资源探索的方向。”他引用周末在数码港举行的数字娱乐领导力论坛时写道。

;

;第一代互联网出现于20世纪90年代，简称Web1。它主要由静态网页组成，内容用于显示信息。

;

;Web2 是互联网的现状，据信始于世纪之交，其特点是社交媒体平台和电子商务。

;

;Web3 是假设的下一代万维网版本，它通过使用区块链和类似技术实现去中心化和分布式。

;

;Chan强调Web3技术将不仅仅局限于在线娱乐或虚拟资产。

;

;“通过技术创新和应用创新，可以解决金融、企业运营、贸易等领域遇到的诸多困难和痛点。” 、供应链管理甚至日常生活。”

;

;他表示，政府正在寻找应用 Web3 技术的方法，并补充说香港金融管理局已发行了世界上第一个政府支持的代币化绿色货币

;

;香港将举办夜市、组织会议以刺激经济：陈茂波

;

;“这将债券和其他金融工具、参与者和相关活动聚集在一个单一的平台上数字平台。这提高了效率，将债券发行的处理时间从通常的五个工作日缩短到一个工作日。”陈说。

;

;官员们承诺加大对 Web3 数字经济的投资，使这座城市

;

;财政司司长在 2023-24 年度财政预算案中宣布成立专责小组，就 Web3 在香港的可持续和负责任发展提供建议。

;

;复苏香港航空业“近在眼前”；该市寻求航空服务交易

;

;该工作组由陈领导，于 6 月成立，并有 15 名行业专家作为非官方成员。陈伟霆表示，该小组已经召开。

;

;他还在2月份的2023-24年度财政预算案中拨款5,000万港元，以加快Web3生态系统的发展，包括举办国际研讨会、促进跨界别业务合作

;

;陈表示，超过180家Web3相关公司已在数码港设立办事处，其中超过五分之一来自中国内地或海外。

;香港资讯科技商会名誉会长方宝侨要求政府加快制定Web3的全面监管框架，并加强公众教育。

;

;环境生态局局长谢展云周日表示，公众和学者可能希望获得更多信息，因为目前的测试政府公布的结果只是显示样品是否通过。

;

;“我可以回去和我的同事讨论这个想法，”谢在接受电视采访时说。 “也许过一段时间，我们可以做一个分析，可以把一些数据公布出来，分析比较，让大家充分看到数据是什么样的。”

;

;政府开始发布基本数据在日本上周开始将废弃的福岛核电站的含氚放射性废水排放到太平洋后，对从日本进口的食品和城市渔业进行的放射性测试结果。

;

;联合国核能监管机构——国际原子能机构——上个月签署了该计划，认为该计划是安全的。预计需要30年才能处理掉所有的水。

;

;香港还全面禁止进口来自东京、福岛、千叶、栃木、茨城、群马、宫城、新泻、长野的海产品和埼玉县。

;

;谢强调，政府认为人们最关心的是产品是否通过测试，因此信息仅限于基本细节。

;但他说一些市民及学者可能想了解更多资料。

;

;食物安全中心于8月24日中午至8月25日中午检测的247个日本进口食品样本全部被评为“合格”。

;

; p>;

;渔农自然护理署表示，周六中午至周日中午测试的50个来自香港的水产品样本也录得“满意”结果。

;

;胡绍山教授，教育大学的一位海洋生态学专家表示，不需要花太多精力就可以将辐射测试样品分为不同类别，例如鱼、牡蛎、蛤，以及每个类别中有多少产品（如果有的话）超出了辐射限值。

;

;香港对福岛废水排放计划的回应

;

;

;政府目前没有按来自日本或日本的海鲜类型提供任何详细信息。

;

;吴说，不同国家的测试辐射水平限制不同，香港政府需要“说明他们使用的限制是什么”。

;

;Nigel澳大利亚科廷大学物理学副教授马克斯表示，他相信公共教育将有助于打击有关健康风险的错误信息，而不是贴上标签。

;

;“这些额外的信息只会让一些人比以往任何时候都更加困惑。然后会有另一部分人会想，谁在乎呢，我喜欢鱼，我要去吃它，”他说。

;

;谢还呼吁日本释放更多鱼氚是一种难以分离的氢放射性同位素，处理后的放射性废水排放的测试信息。

;

;他补充说，日本还应该让该地区和国际社会参与设计和设计。放射性废水排放系统的认证。

;

;谢周日还澄清了目前日本进口水产品的辐射测试流程。他说，当局主要测试伽马辐射，但他们会检查一些产品的α和β辐射，这需要更长的时间。

;

;尽管联合国批准，香港仍然对日本放射性水排放计划保持警惕

;

;这三种类型的辐射是最常见的形式。

;

;谢表示，为了防止延误，当局将允许通过伽马辐射测试的产品首先通过，但他们可能会采取一些样本进行进一步检测，作为监测整体情况的一部分。

;

;这一消息传出之际，香港行政长官李家超表示政府必须采取“严厉和严肃的措施”在日本决定将受污染的水排入大海后，为了确保食品安全和保护公众健康。

;

;这位市领导首次公开谈论这个问题，尽管他抨击日本“强行实施其上周二在 Facebook 上发帖称，“不负责任地给他人带来问题”。

;

;李在周日就其 10 月份施政报告进行公众咨询后发表讲话，称东京计划在 2017 年排放 132 万吨处理过的放射性废水。 30年是“史无前例”的，所以不能称为无风险。

;

;“世界上还没有看到任何系统或方法是无风险、无人类的”李说。

;

;他补充说，该市迄今为止采取的所有措施都是为了确保公众在参观餐馆或购买食品时不必担心食品安全。 .

;

;香港最高法院的一项裁决给违反国家安全法的人带来了新的不确定性法律专家警告称，认罪不再保证减刑三分之一。

;

;他们表示，这一具有里程碑意义的决定为未来的国家安全审判设定了量刑基准，其中包括一项备受瞩目的涉及国家安全的审判。 29 名反对派政客和活动人士因三年前在一次非官方初选中所扮演的角色而承认颠覆罪。

;

;根据普通法制度，法院经常因认罪而将刑期减少三分之一。

;

; p>;

;周二，终审法院拒绝为一名承认煽动分裂国家的大学生减刑五年。裁定较轻的刑罚仍须在严重国家安全犯罪规定的最低限度内。

;

;香港法院批准针对16名反对派人士的颠覆罪案

;

;学者和律师告诉《华盛顿邮报》，维持对吕世瑜的最低刑罚，会给未来打算认罪的被告带来不确定性。

;

;“这意味着，对于那些考虑认罪的被告来说，他们必须告知，仅仅认罪或其他减刑因素不会将最终刑期减至低于规定的最低刑期，除非属于国家安全法第33条规定的三个类别之一，”香港大学前法律系主任陈文文告诉《邮报》。

;

;第33条规定，如果情节轻微，法院可以从轻处罚、减轻处罚或者不予考虑。被告人“主动停止犯罪”、“有效预防后果”、主动自首、举报他人犯罪行为或者协助解决其他国家安全案件。

;

;非正式初选颠覆审判，四名活动人士和前政客——前立法会议员区诺轩、前区议员赵家贤、钟锦伦，以及商人林景南——选择出庭作为控方证人。

;

;“只有三个条件才能产生减刑或减轻刑罚的实际效果，从而激励被告选择举报他人可能犯下的国家安全法罪行或成为控方证人，”乔治城大学亚洲法中心研究员黎彦豪表示。

;

;他表示，“当香港的普通法惯例不再可靠时，确定性就被打破了”。

;

; >;

;“这给被告带来了一个困难的处境，因为他们永远不知道法院在认罪之前是否考虑过他们实施国家安全法的性质，”他补充道。 “这使得认罪后减刑的效用变得很低。”

;

;不过，港大法律学者陈弘毅却不同意，他认为作为普通刑事案件的法官，这种不确定性可以忽略不计。无论如何，可能不会考虑减轻法律规定的最高刑期。

;

;香港国安警察讯问通缉活动人士郭安娜的兄弟

;

;减刑仍然对被告有利他说，因为他们只能根据无罪释放的可能性来选择是否承认指控，而不是减轻刑罚。

;

;“首先，被告不会知道如果他们的罪行被认为是严重的。如果不是，则不适用最低刑罚。”陈说。

;

;驳斥了这种安排会使被告处于不利地位的观点，陈说，被告有无法判断他们的刑期起点在哪里。

;

;但陈同时警告说，成为控方证人并不会自动满足第33条进一步减刑的要求.

;

;“在同一案件中担任控方证人（多名被告）可能不符合第33条第3款，”陈说。

;

;香港不应采取强硬态度法学教授称“软抵抗”

;学生占网络裸照勒索案件受害者的五分之一香港警方透露，今年上半年，一名 11 岁男孩被引诱下载了一款在其智能手机上植入恶意软件的应用程序。

; Mon, 28 Aug 2023 15:20:01 +0800 Hong Kong employers of Indonesian domestic helpers do not need to pay ‘thousands of dollars’ more as hiring policy will stay unchanged, country’s envoy to city sayshttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3232450/hong-kong-employers-indonesian-domestic-helpers-do-not-need-pay-thousands-dollars-more-hiring-policy?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;印尼驻香港外交官向雇主保证政策没有变化与从东南亚国家招聘家庭佣工有关。

;

;印度尼西亚负责礼宾和领事事务的领事克莱门斯·特里亚吉·贝克蒂库苏马（Clemens Triaji Bektikusuma）建议雇主使用经过认可的机构，以避免收取过高费用。

;

; 262 employment agencies accredited by the consulate, but he knew of more than 1,000 unaccredited ones whose practices posed a risk to both workers and Hong Kong employers, he said.

;

;His remarks cleared up recent confusion over whether employers would have to pay considerably more to hire helpers from Indonesia.

;

;The Jakarta-based Indonesian Manpower Placement Agency Association (Aspataki) announced earlier this month that Jakarta would implement its “zero placement fee” policy fully and employers would have to pay a few thousand more Hong Kong dollars.

;

;The news upset employers and led to a protest outside the Indonesian consulate by dozens of helpers who demanded that Jakarta tackle overcharging by placement agencies that hurt them and their employers.

;

;On August 10, Hong Kong Secretary for Labour and Welfare Chris Sun Yuk-han met Indonesia's acting consul general Slamet Noegroho and concluded that there was no change in the fees for bringing helpers to the city, but he did not make clear if Aspataki's claim would take effect for local employers.

;

;In an interview with the Post on Wednesday, Bektikusuma expressed “deep regret” that Aspataki's announcement had resulted in confusion.

;

; “It is very unfortunate that there were statements by an unauthorised party claiming to represent the whole system and that [this] led to speculative news. It does not only irritate the Hong Kong public but there are also effects for the Indonesian domestic helpers,” he said.

;

;He emphasised that employers did not need to pay extra if they went through accredited agencies which were closely monitored by the consulate to ensure their practices were in line with the regulations.

;

;Among other things, the consulate checked the size of the agencies, the number of staff and accommodation for newly arrived workers.

;

;He said there were unaccredited agencies in Hong Kong that could charge employers more because they operated like “subagencies” and went through the accredited agencies to process the formalities involved in employing helpers.

;

;Some agents told the Post that the costs related to Indonesia's zero placement fee policy – revised twice by Jakarta in 2020 and last year to protect workers from falling into debt – had already been absorbed in recent years. Under the policy, helpers do not need to pay a job placement fee.

;

;Thomas Chan Tung-fung, chairman of the Hong Kong Union of Employment Agencies, said the fee had been “gradually” passed on to the employers and reflected the “simple logic of how business works”.

;

;He estimated that employers paid between HK$10,000 and HK$12,000 (US$1,274 and US$1,529) to recruit an Indonesian helper before 2020, and that had gone up by HK$3,000 to HK$4,000 over the past three years.

;

;He said the extra cost did not cover a training fee, which was supposed to have been borne by Jakarta.

;

;But Chan said the Indonesian agencies did not receive that money from their government, and Aspataki then claimed there was a new fee employers had to pay, which would eventually pass on to the workers if employers failed to shoulder it.

;

;Indonesian domestic helpers in Hong Kong protest against agencies 'overcharging'

;

;Chan felt the cause of the confusion lay in the communication between the Indonesian agencies and Jakarta authorities.

;

;Hong Kong Employment Agencies Association chairman Cheung Kit-man said it appeared that the Indonesian authorities and agencies were not aligned on how to implement the zero placement fee policy.

;

;He said that Jakarta had pressured agencies there to enforce the policy without realising the demand and standards expected in Hong Kong.

;

;“Does the market have enough experienced workers to offer? Are the workers well-trained? Are the documents all ready to proceed,” Cheung asked.

;

;Some extra fees were incurred because of extra training given to inexperienced workers, or those from rural areas who did not have the complete identification documents.

;

;In such cases, it did not make sense for Jakarta to expect employers to bear the additional cost and the authorities there left it to the Indonesian agents and workers to deal with, he said.

;

;Cheung, who operates six employment agencies in Hong Kong, said he had complied with the policy and already raised the recruitment fee by about HK$5,000 over the years.

;

;Bektikusuma agreed that the decision to raise in placement fees involved “business-to-business relations” between agencies in Hong Kong and Indonesia.

;

;He said the consulate had drawn up “a strict, comprehensive mechanism” to share all processes involved with the agencies, while maintaining close coordination with Hong Kong's Labour Department and Immigration Department.

;

;The diplomat added that all Hong Kong accredited agencies were subject to a yearly review by the consulate.

;

;Rights groups urge Hong Kong to raise wages for domestic helpers by 27 per cent

;

;There are currently about 140,000 Indonesian domestic helpers in Hong Kong, accounting for more than two-fifths of the 338,000 such foreign workers in the city, according to official data.

;

;Although Jakarta had been trying to reduce the burden on the workers, Bektikusuma acknowledged that some were still overcharged when making arrangements to work in the city.

;

;But he said there were limits to what the Indonesian authorities could do.

;

;“Overcharging is much more a matter between the Hong Kong and Indonesian employment agencies,” he said.

;

;No rule change for Hongkongers hiring Indonesian domestic helpers: labour chief

;

;If overcharging occurred in Indonesia, he was confident the country's law enforcement agencies would deal with the complaints.

;

;“But the Indonesian consulate will not interfere in cases that happen in Hong Kong,” he said.

;

;Bektikusuma invited local authorities to work with the consulate to review the system to ensure better protection for the workers.

;

;“We need to sit together, to monitor and evaluate whether there are steps that we need to change,” he said.

; Mon, 28 Aug 2023 15:20:01 +0800 Former Kowloon Walled City resident takes Hong Kong government to court over 4-time rejection of public housing applicationhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3232455/former-kowloon-walled-city-resident-takes-hong-kong-government-court-over-4-time-rejection-public?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;A former Kowloon Walled City resident will take the Hong Kong government to court after his application for public housing was rejected four times, contesting an eligibility clause that bars him because he accepted compensation when the area was demolished.

;

;The retiree surnamed Hui filed a judicial review and accused authorities of “unfair treatment” over a policy that made him ineligible for government housing because he had accepted the financial package 30 years ago when his home in the Kowloon Walled City was knocked down.

;

;“They reject me for the same reason every time, so I have no choice but to appeal through legal means,” the 74-year-old said.

;

;Those who accepted the money are considered to have opted to make their own accommodation arrangements under Housing Authority guidelines and cannot apply for public rental flats.

;

;Inside Kowloon Walled City: 'I knew I was somewhere extraordinary'

;

;But those reimbursed because of more recent redevelopment projects or clearance of squatter areas can apply for two years after receiving payment.

;

;Hui accepted the deal in 1993 and received HK$70,000, the equivalent of HK$131,237 (US$16,747) nowadays, as compensation for the demolition of a 250 sq ft (23.2 sq m) flat he co-owned with a friend in the 1980s.

;

;The Kowloon Walled City was a densely populated enclave near the former Kai Tak airport that spanned 2.7 hectares (6.67 acres).

;

;The area was infamous for its opium parlours and gambling dens run by triads before it was knocked down in the run-up to Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.

;

;The government offered residents the chance to relocate to public housing or be compensated the market price for their flats.

;

;Hui said he and his friend had decided to split the HK$140,000 on offer.

;

;“I chose to buy a unit in the Walled City precisely because they were cheaper due to the difficult environment. Flats on the market then cost HK$200,000 to HK$300,000, so HK$70,000 could not buy me anything,” he said.

;

;Hui worked as a dim sum chef after leaving the enclave and was offered free accommodation with the job. He later switched to renting a subdivided flat in Yau Ma Tei when he became a security guard.

;

;But a workplace injury in 2019 left him unemployed and living on the streets before the Society for Community Organization (SoCO) offered him a temporary place to stay and support to apply for public housing.

;

;A look back at life inside Hong Kong's Kowloon Walled City

;

;“He is 74 and unable to find any more work due to his age and arm injury. We feel that as an elderly resident, he should have a roof over his head,” SoCO community organiser Ng Wai-tung, who is helping Hui apply for legal aid, said.

;

;“The Housing Authority doesn't have an appeal system, so we are taking this to the High Court, because we have exhausted all appeal procedures.”

;

;Hui also receives financial support from the Comprehensive Social Security Assistance (CSSA) scheme for Hongkongers with assets of less than HK$35,000 and is at present staying at a transitional housing flat, but must leave after two years.

;

;He said he felt the rejection of his public housing applications was unjustified because authorities still accepted those who had bought subsidised housing, but later faced circumstances such as divorce, bankruptcy or other financial hardships.

;

;“I applied for CSSA thinking that I could apply for public housing through this exemption, but they still rejected me because I previously received compensation from the government and will not be eligible for any more subsidised housing,” he said.

;

;“That is very unfair.”

;

;The Housing Authority declined to comment as legal proceedings are under way.

; Mon, 28 Aug 2023 15:20:01 +0800 Crystal meth worth HK$170 million hidden in leather rolls seized in Hong Kong as part of international anti-drug trafficking operationhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3232503/crystal-meth-worth-hk170-million-hidden-leather-rolls-seized-hong-kong-part-international-anti-drug?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.28 11:05;
;;

;An international anti-drug trafficking operation between Hong Kong and overseas law enforcement agencies has led to the seizure of suspected crystal meth worth HK$170 million (US$26.7 million) from Mexico bound for Australia and the arrest of four people, customs has revealed.

;

;Customs officers on Monday said they confiscated 240kg (529 lbs) of the drug in the city, which was concealed in synthetic leather rolls. Three local residents were also arrested on Thursday and Friday last week.

;

;The transnational operation also led Australian authorities to arrest a 28-year-old man in Sydney last Wednesday.

;

;Superintendent Henry Fong Heung-wing of customs' drug investigation bureau on Monday said the street value of the haul would have surged two to three times if it was sold in Australia.

;

;The amount marked the largest single seizure of illegal drugs by customs this year, he added.

;

;Hong Kong police seize meth worth HK$123 million, in biggest such haul this year

;

;He said investigations with overseas law enforcement agencies were ongoing, and further arrests had not been ruled out.

;

;Customs began investigating the shipment after receiving intelligence from overseas counterparts in July.

;

;After spending about 10 days analysing data in the pre-declaration system for shipments from America, they identified the suspicious package from Mexico, which was then selected for inspection when it arrived in the city on July 12.

;

;The shipment was declared to be carrying more than 600 artificial leather rolls, which raised suspicions because the good rarely came from Mexico, according to Assistant Superintendent Alex Wong Kei-cheung, head of customs' containerised cargo examination division.

;

;He said X-rays of the cargo had revealed suspicious material in 40 of the artificial leather rolls, which each had a label stuck to them.

;

;“We unrolled the 40 rolls for further inspection and discovered the illegal drug,” he said.

;

;“Each roll was hiding 91 vacuumed plastic packages and each package contained 65 grams of suspected crystal meth,” Fong said.

;

;Hong Kong teenager arrested, HK$8.3 million worth of drugs seized in police raid

;

;The operation resulted in the seizure of 240kg of the narcotic in total, with an estimated street value of HK$170 million in Hong Kong, he added.

;

;According to the shipping document, the consignee is a textile company in the city.

;

;About 100 customs officers were then deployed to work around the clock for the next three weeks to carry out a controlled delivery and monitor the package.

;

;It was transported to three container yards in Tuen Mun, Tin Shui Wan and Kwai Chung, but no one collected the cargo.

;

;Investigations revealed that the shipment was bound for Sydney, which prompted customs to immediately seek assistance from Australian authorities to monitor the package.

;

;Fong said the shipment left Hong Kong without the drug on August 2 and arrived in Sydney on August 13. It was picked up for delivery on August 21.

;

;Two days later, Australian authorities arrested a 28-year-old man who was accused of arranging the delivery and renting premises to store the package.

;

;In the following days, Hong Kong customs officers swooped into action and arrested three men in connection with the case.

;

;Largest haul yet as Hong Kong customs seizes goods smuggled via Singapore

;

;One of the men was the owner of the textile company, while the other two were in charge of two logistics companies. The three residents have been released on bail pending further investigation.

;

;Superintendent Fong said the seizure showed the effectiveness of international cooperation between Hong Kong and overseas law enforcement agencies.

;

;He said customs would continue to cooperate and exchange intelligence with overseas agencies to combat international drug trafficking at its source.

;

;Hong Kong customs has confiscated 4.2 tonnes of narcotics this year as of last Wednesday, a nearly 40 per cent surge from about 3 tonnes discovered in the same period in 2022.

;

;During the same period this year, officers seized 679kg of crystal meth in the city from the Americas bound for Asia Pacific countries such as Australia and New Zealand.

;

;In all of 2022, officers found 2,630kg of meth on the same route. In one of the cases, customs seized HK$1.1 billion worth of liquid meth from Mexico disguised as cartons of coconut water, making it the largest-ever haul of the illegal drug.

;

;“We will not allow Hong Kong to be a transit port for illegal drugs. That's why we connected overseas law enforcement agencies to mount this transnational controlled delivery operation,” the superintendent said, referring to the latest incident.

;

;“We will adjust our enforcement strategies in a timely manner to cope with ever-changing drug smuggling trends.”

;

;Professor Kenneth Leung Mei-yee, who chairs the Advisory Council on Food and Environmental Hygiene, told a radio programme that Tokyo Electric Power Company (TEPCO) had only released a report on the levels of tritium in seawater samples but left out other radioactive materials and seabed sediments.

;Leung expressed concern that some substances might not be detectable in initial tests because of their lower radiation levels, adding that these could end up in the seabed over time due to currents and gravity, leading to higher concentrations.

;

;“We have to consider how reliable the data is given it was unilaterally released by TEPCO. I hope Japan will allow inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) to run the tests to see if their findings are in line with those of the power company. Matching reports will help regain the confidence of the public,” he said.

;

;Hong Kong last Thursday banned aquatic products from 10 Japanese prefectures – Tokyo, Fukushima, Chiba, Tochigi, Ibaraki, Gunma, Miyagi, Niigata, Nagano and Saitama. The policy covers live, chilled, frozen, dried and preserved goods, sea salt and raw or processed seaweed items.

;

;The Japanese power company, which operates the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant, released its report last Friday showing no detectable amount of tritium had been found in seawater samples taken from 10 locations within a distance of 3km (2 miles) of the site, hours after the water discharge began the day before.

;

;Leung, also the chair professor of the department of chemistry at City University, said more than 1,000 tanks had stored the radioactive waste water over the past 12 years since the Fukushima nuclear disaster in 2011, accounting for more than 1 million metric tons of treated water.

;

;Full release of Hong Kong tests on seafood from Japan and city waters possible

;

;He said Japan might only release the water from the tanks that had been storing it for a shorter period of time as the liquid in the ones that had kept it for a longer duration was “way more contaminated” and could cause the current processing system for dilution to overload.

;

;The Japanese power company said it planned to continue taking daily seawater samples for analysis and would publicly disclose the results the following day for about a month.

;

;The Ministry of Environment of Japan also said it would analyse seawater samples every week for about three months.

;

;Leung said keeping an eye on the reports in the long run was paramount as he expected a third party such as the IAEA to contribute to the testing and verify if the data from Japan was reliable.

;

;Hong Kong unlikely to extend seafood ban beyond 10 Japanese prefectures: minister

;

;Hong Kong Secretary for Environment and Ecology Tse Chin-wan on Sunday said authorities would consider releasing the full details of their radioactivity test results on seafood imported from Japan and marine produce from city waters.

;

;Current test results released by the government only showed whether samples had passed or failed.

;

;Leung on Monday said the city had set a “very high standard” for food safety measures as the ban on Japanese seafood covered 10 prefectures. He urged the public not to worry about such food items in the city as they had passed multiple tests before hitting the shelves.

;

;

;He added that it was “possible” that Hong Kong could relax the restrictions if data from the countries in the same seafood trading community showed no detection of radioactive substances in fishery products in the next few years.

;

;Hong Kong is Japan's second-largest market for fisheries exports, with mainland China being the largest.

;

;The city imported Japanese marine products worth about 51.6 billion yen (US$352.3 million) in the first six months of the year, accounting for a quarter of the country's exports for the sector, according to official figures from the country.
